title: 108_s519
content: The Act titled as the "Indian Tribal Development Corporation Feasibility Study Act of 2004" mandates a feasibility study. The Native American Business Development, Trade Promotion, and Tourism Act of 2000 is amended to establish the Tribal Development Corporation Feasibility Study Group with 12 members, including representatives of Indian tribes and Alaska Natives. The Tribal Development Corporation Feasibility Study Group consists of 12 members, including representatives of the Alaska Native Community, Native Hawaiian Community, private sector, and federal officials from the Department of the Treasury. The Tribal Development Corporation Feasibility Study Group, consisting of 12 members, includes representatives from the Alaska Native Community, Native Hawaiian Community, private sector, and federal officials from the Department of the Treasury. The Group may appoint a Chairperson, hire necessary personnel and services, and procure services to perform its duties. The Tribal Development Corporation Feasibility Study Group, with 12 members, will conduct a study to determine the feasibility of establishing an Indian Tribal Development Corporation. They will submit their findings to relevant Senate committees. The Tribal Development Corporation Feasibility Study Group, consisting of 12 members, will assess the feasibility of creating an Indian Tribal Development Corporation. They will present a report to the House of Representatives Appropriations Committee detailing the financial viability and potential economic impact of the Corporation. The feasibility study group will determine the economic impact of the Corporation on Native American communities, discuss alternative structures and lending terms, and assess the best capital contributions to serve Native interests. The curr_chunk discusses the terms and conditions for funding member Indian tribes and nonfinancial activities to be undertaken by the Corporation, including diagnostic studies to identify obstacles to investment. The curr_chunk provides specific recommendations for Indian tribes to overcome obstacles that hinder investment, and it establishes terms for pre-appraisal studies of investment opportunities. The curr_chunk discusses the capital structure and financial instruments needed for the success of a Corporation that can be developed and promoted by an Indian tribe. The curr_chunk discusses the termination of a study group after submitting a report and authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 2005 and 2006. The curr_chunk states that the bill was passed by the Senate on November 19, 2004.
